Posted By: NoobOfLore (12/11/2010 5:14:05 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Destroying Creatures feels very black but creating [balance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=balance) by cleaning the WHOLE field is very white. So it fits both colors very well. People that dont understand why WoG is a white spell are ignorant.   
Also in what it actually does, it has more defensive values and white always has been the main color for board effects especially mass removal.  
I bet if WoG would have said exile instead of destroy, black players wouldnt argue about it being white.  
  
[Plague Wind](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plague Wind) for reference is definitly black and a white version wouldnt be flavorful  
  
Also remember that this set is planar chaos, which is about color bleed, where for example, green gets non condotional card draw ([Harmonize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Harmonize)) and white direct damage ([Sunlance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sunlance)). I am not saying damnation doesnt makes sense in black flavor wise (because it does) but R&D just decided that Board Sweepers like WoG belong to white in the color pie. (Mainly to balance the color p... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:

Also in what it actually does, it has more defensive values and white always has been the main color for board effects especially mass removal.
I bet if WoG would have said exile instead of destroy, black players wouldnt argue about it being white.

Plague Wind for reference is definitly black and a white version wouldnt be flavorful

Also remember that this set is planar chaos, which is about color bleed, where for example, green gets non condotional card draw (Harmonize) and white direct damage (Sunlance). I am not saying damnation doesnt makes sense in black flavor wise (because it does) but R&D just decided that Board Sweepers like WoG belong to white in the color pie.
